Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story:
I stood in the crowded room, balancing a glass of punch, when a familiar face from my neighborhood approached. “Hey, you’re a lawyer, right? I heard you’re working on that big case—what’s it about?” he asked, his tone light but his eyes curious. My mind raced. As a lawyer, I knew I couldn’t reveal anything about my client, not even the nature of the case. But as a neighbor and a voter, I felt the pressure to be open, to connect, to not seem secretive or aloof. 

At the same time, I remembered that my only chance to grab my valid ID for voting was this morning, before work swallowed the rest of my day. If I left now, I’d miss out on valuable networking, but if I stayed, I risked forgetting the ID and losing my chance to vote. The expectations pressed in from both sides—professional secrecy and civic responsibility. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands, feeling the tension twist inside me, unsure which role to honor first.
